prefix: Approach the following question the way someone in high school would.
problem_prompt: Approach the following question the way someone in high school would. What integer $n$ satisfies $0\le n<19$ and $$-200\equiv n\pmod{19}~?$$
solution: Noticing that $190\equiv0\pmod{19}$ and $-200+190=-10$, we can say that  \[-200\equiv n\pmod{19}\]if and only if  \[-10\equiv n\pmod{19}.\]This is not in the range $0\leq n<19$, but adding 19 again gives \[9\equiv n\pmod{19}.\]The answer is $n=\boxed{9}$.
gpt_response:
To find the integer $n$ that satisfies $0\le n < 19$ and $-200 \equiv n \pmod{19}$, we can start by finding the remainder when $-200$ is divided by $19$. 

When we divide $-200$ by $19$, we get a quotient of $-10$ and a remainder of $9$. This means that $-200 = 19(-10) + 9$. 

Since we want to find an integer $n$ that satisfies $0 \le n < 19$ and $-200 \equiv n \pmod{19}$, we can see that $n$ should be $9$ because it is the remainder when $-200$ is divided by $19$. 

Thus, the integer $n$ that satisfies $0\le n < 19$ and $-200\equiv n\pmod{19}$ is $9$.
